Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Socioeconomic and Spatio-Temporal Dimensions of the Geography of Food Access

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will investigate food access and food security issues by assessing how people's daily activities, the spatial and temporal dimensions of their urban trip-making, and their demographic and socioeconomic characteristics affect the ways food is accessed by different populations. Special attention will be focused on the ability of low-income and disadvantaged populations to access food and nutrition-assistance services. The project will provide new knowledge regarding the geography of food access, time geography, and location science by providing a new perspective for better understanding the complexity of food access that explicitly incorporates travel patters with socioeconomic characteristics rather than relying on more traditional, simplistic measures that focused on spatial proximity and distance between homes and food stores. The project will provide new insights into travel-related issues associated with access to food and nutrition-assistance services for the low-income population, the elderly, and other disadvantaged groups with special needs, and the new spatial optimization model will contribute to the literature in location science that largely has focused on the spatial context and ignored the temporal variation of supply and demand across space. The project will yield a more suitable planning mechanism for service and facility planning that incorporates the spatial and temporal patterns of the population demand. The project's emphasis on food access for low-income and other disadvantaged populations will offer insights to agencies, groups, and policy makers seeking to improve access and service to food. Because the doctoral student is working with a local government agency, she will make readily accessible models and findings that can help the agency determine the best sites and time windows for providing food and nutrition assistance. Although this project is being conducted in Tucson, Arizona, project findings and outcomes will be adaptable for many other settings. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

During the course of this project, the doctoral student will investigate how people's decisions about whether, where, and when to obtain food are affected by their daily activities and travel patterns. She will examine the space-time access patterns of low-income population for food-assistance services, and she will compare them with the food-access patterns of the general population. She also will develop and test new models that incorporate people's daily travel patterns into planning for food and nutrition assistance. She will use a unique household travel dataset with detailed space-time travel activities as well as data on emergency food services sponsored by The Emergency Food Assistance Program, a federally sponsored program that helps supplement the diets of low-income population in order to relieve hunger on a short-term basis. The student will conduct questionnaires, interviews, and focus group studies at diverse food-access points to identify travel patterns and the needs of the disadvantaged populations. In the final stage of the project, she will develop spatial optimization models will be developed that incorporate travel dynamics into service-facility planning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focuses on the investigation of urban food access and food assistance service in several different aspects, including but not limited to food environment and accessibility assessment, food and nutrition assistance service planning, individual-based access and food/store choice modeling in the context of daily activity and travel dynamics. We conducted both qualitative (i.e. survey, questionnaire, and interview) and quantitative (i.e. statistics, spatial analysis, GIS, and optimization modelling) analyses to improve our understanding on urban food access. The intellectual merits of the project are summarized as follows.

Frist, the study has contributed to explaining the inconsistent findings reported in existing studies regarding the relationship between neighborhood characteristics and food accessibility. We found that the effects of spatial scale/unit (i.e. census tract, block group, and zip code) and aggregation methods (i.e. geographic center, population center, and population weighted measure) on accessibility assessment pose serious challenges to policy design and should be treated carefully.

Second, we incorporated independent grocers and store diversity in food environment evaluation to fill the gap that non-chain stores are often left out in accessibility assessment. The empirical study indicates that full-service independent grocers help fill some voids left by chain markets, as well as improve the diversity of food providers available to low-income populations. We also noticed that some independent stores serve food deserts in racially/ethnically diverse neighborhoods where a higher proportion of residents rely on public assistance program (i.e. SNAP and WIC) and have limited mobility. Our study suggests that smaller grocers have great potential to serve food deserts, particularly if policy incentives can be provided.

Third, analysis of travel diary data has addressed the discrepancies between realized access by individuals and theoretical neighborhood accessibility. We found that in reality people do not necessarily go to the nearest store to their home location, which has been assumed in the neighborhood food environment assessment. But proximity is still an important factor; other factors include market structure, neighborhood environment, consumer characteristics, and trip-chaining behavior. Take commuting trip as an example, about half of the sampled commuters chose stores closer to work and the other half picked stores closer to home. Either way, the store is seated along the commuting trip or does not deviate far from the route. We believe this should be of substantial significance for policy-making and offers insights that should aid government agencies as well as retailers in formulating more efficient and effective approaches and strategies.

Fourth, survey and interview at food assistance agencies along with data analysis on food box distribution has revealed some underlying dynamics behind the spatial mismatch of service site and recipients’ residence. In addition to time constraint and trip related reasons, the operating scheme, location (i.e. close to public transportation), schedule, and the amount and quality of food at various food assistance service sites all play important roles. In particular, the atmosphere at the distribution sites and relationship between the agency and the recipients could lead to long term customer loyalty. Above all, making information readily available to food assistance participants in a meaningful manner (i.e. show it on map instead of a list of addresses) is vital to increase the system efficiency and adjusting the temporal arrangement at different agencies is key to making service more convenient to disadvantaged group and improving the effectiveness of service planning.

Last, a spatial optimization model was developed to offer new insights on alleviating food desert problem and to provide spatial and marketing strategies to local small grocers to serve niche markets and unmet demand in underserved neighborhoods. Our methods can be used by government officials, non-profit organizations and the private sector to plan their food provision service and formulate locational strategy.

In sum, the research findings have important implications for service and facility planning for both government and non-government agencies, including non-profit organization, community advocates, and retailers. Throughout the project, we have worked very closely with local communities including local food banks, community centers, and small non-chain grocers, as well as the University of Arizona’s Bureau of Applied Research in Anthropology. The focus on low-income and minority population and food desert offers insights to policy-makers in food and nutrition assistance service provisions. Meanwhile, we have promoted teaching, training, and learning by recruiting and working with undergraduate and graduate students on data collection and survey analysis. Results and findings have been shared with community organizations, research partners, city officials and scholars in the field. The project has resulted in one dissertation and two research papers with another two manuscripts under preparation for journal submission. 

 


Last Modified: 01/08/2018
Modified by: Yang Bao
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project focuses on the investigation of urban food access and food assistance service in several different aspects, including but not limited to food environment and accessibility assessment, food and nutrition assistance service planning, individual-based access and food/store choice modeling in the context of daily activity and travel dynamics. We conducted both qualitative (i.e. survey, questionnaire, and interview) and quantitative (i.e. statistics, spatial analysis, GIS, and optimization modelling) analyses to improve our understanding on urban food access. The intellectual merits of the project are summarized as follows. Frist, the study has contributed to explaining the inconsistent findings reported in existing studies regarding the relationship between neighborhood characteristics and food accessibility. We found that the effects of spatial scale/unit (i.e. census tract, block group, and zip code) and aggregation methods (i.e. geographic center, population center, and population weighted measure) on accessibility assessment pose serious challenges to policy design and should be treated carefully. Second, we incorporated independent grocers and store diversity in food environment evaluation to fill the gap that non-chain stores are often left out in accessibility assessment. The empirical study indicates that full-service independent grocers help fill some voids left by chain markets, as well as improve the diversity of food providers available to low-income populations. We found that in reality people do not necessarily go to the nearest store to their home location, which has been assumed in the neighborhood food environment assessment. Either way, the store is seated along the commuting trip or does not deviate far from the route. Fourth, survey and interview at food assistance agencies along with data analysis on food box distribution has revealed some underlying dynamics behind the spatial mismatch of service site and recipients? residence. In addition to time constraint and trip related reasons, the operating scheme, location (i.e. close to public transportation), schedule, and the amount and quality of food at various food assistance service sites all play important roles. In particular, the atmosphere at the distribution sites and relationship between the agency and the recipients could lead to long term customer loyalty. Last, a spatial optimization model was developed to offer new insights on alleviating food desert problem and to provide spatial and marketing strategies to local small grocers to serve niche markets and unmet demand in underserved neighborhoods. Our methods can be used by government officials, non-profit organizations and the private sector to plan their food provision service and formulate locational strategy. In sum, the research findings have important implications for service and facility planning for both government and non-government agencies, including non-profit organization, community advocates, and retailers. Throughout the project, we have worked very closely with local communities including local food banks, community centers, and small non-chain grocers, as well as the University of Arizona?s Bureau of Applied Research in Anthropology. The focus on low-income and minority population and food desert offers insights to policy-makers in food and nutrition assistance service provisions. Meanwhile, we have promoted teaching, training, and learning by recruiting and working with undergraduate and graduate students on data collection and survey analysis. Results and findings have been shared with community organizations, research partners, city officials and scholars in the field. The project has resulted in one dissertation and two research papers with another two manuscripts under preparation for journal submission. Last Modified: 01/08/2018 Submitted by: Yang Bao
